plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A deciduous tree known for its large, tulip-shaped flowers that often appear before the leaves. The flowers are usually white to pink-purple and emit a light fragrance.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Asia and cultivated widely in North America and Europe
plants.funFact: Saucer Magnolias are among the earliest flowering trees, often blooming even before the last frost has passed.

plants.name: Erysimum cheiri
plants.description: A biennial or short-lived perennial plant with clusters of fragrant, brightly colored flowers. Wallflowers thrive on walls, rocky places, and garden beds.
plants.bloomingSeason: Spring to early summer (April to June)
plants.location: Native to Europe, cultivated in temperate zones worldwide
plants.funFact: Wallflowers release a sweet fragrance especially in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub with leathery leaves and clusters of fragrant flowers. Widely grown as an ornamental plant in subtropical and Mediterranean climates.
plants.location: Mediterranean region, subtropical and tropical parts of the world
plants.funFact: Oleander is highly toxic if ingested, yet has been used historically in traditional medicine with great caution.

plants.name: Rhododendron ponticum
plants.description: A large evergreen shrub that produces dense clusters of bell-shaped flowers in spring. It is considered invasive in some regions due to its aggressive growth.
plants.location: Native to southern Europe and Asia; invasive in parts of the UK and Ireland
plants.funFact: Rhododendron ponticum can be toxic to livestock and humans due to grayanotoxins present in its leaves and flowers.
